FacilityName: CITY OF OXNARD WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Policy:
The City of Oxnard Wastewater Treatment has and continues to design facilities, operate and maintain equipment and commit the personnel and resources to meet or 
exceed industry standards and regulatory requirements.  The City developed and implemented the City's Process Safety Management/ Risk Management Prevention 
Program that provides a systematic approach to employee involvement, safety awareness and program assessment.

Plant Description:
The City of Oxnard Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) is located at 6001 S. Perkins Road, Oxnard, California.   The facility provides secondary treatment for 
wastewater from the Cities of Oxnard, Port Hueneme and other unincorporated areas.  The WWTP is managed, operated and maintained by approximately 75 staff.

The WWTP utilizes several acutely hazardous materials within the treatment process.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide have been identified as acutely hazardous chemicals. 
The facility has inventory capabilities to store 24,000 pounds (12 one-ton containers) of chlorine and 12,000 pounds (6 one-ton containers) of sulfur dioxide. At 
present, the facility is used as stand-by disinfection only! The facility has converted to liquid sodium hypochlorite and sodium bisulfite.

Program Compliance:
The Risk Management Prevention and Process Safety Management Programs have been developed and implemented.  The Risk Management Prevention is fulfillment 
of 40 CFR PART 68.  The Process Safety Management Program is in fulfillment of the Occupational Health and Safety Administration's (OSHA) 1910.119, as well as 
Cal/OSHA's California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials. 

Safety Elements:
The City has maintained a comprehensive program since 1975 and has implemented additional health and safety programs as regulations and prevention programs were 
introduced.  The City received the Large Plant of the Year -1997  for the State of California by t

he California Water Environment Association (CWEA). The award 
recognizes facilities with excellent operation/maintenance performance, proactive health and safety programs and the commitment and resources to implement such 
programs.

The facility has a full-time Safety Officer and a Safety Committee that is comprised of supervisory, administrative, operational and maintenance personnel. The 
Committee has spear-headed several risk reduction projects over the past several years 1999 including:
* Emergency Response Program
* Installation of Wind Socks to assist Emergency Responders
* Installation of remote pneumatic chemical shut-off valves
* De-commissioning of the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Bulk Tanks
* Conversion to liquid Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide in lieu of gaseous acutely hazardous materials

Safety elements can be defined as either administrative or engineering controls.  Administrative elements include; 1) procedural requirements, 2) training, 3) operator 
certification, and 4) City's policy and commitment of resources.  Engineering elements include physical modifications or facilities to 1) detect, 2) contain, 3) treat, 4) 
warn, or 5) eliminate a potential incident.

Recent Conversion to Liquid Chemicals 2001-2002:

As part of the risk reduction effort, the City implemented a Conversion to Liquid Chemical in 2001-2002.  The project allowed the City to remove the gaseous chlorine 
and sulfur dioxide from service.  The existing gaseous facilities were upgraded with a state-of-the-art chlorine gas scrubber and new integrated gas monitoring 
equipment.  The project was awarded Large Engineering Project of the Year by the California Engineering and Land Surveyors (CELSOC) - 2003 CY.


Accident History:

The City has maintained a clean record of accidental releases of acutely hazardous materials and reports no incidents.  The City does maintain a comprehensive Incident 
Investigation and Emergency Response Programs in the event of an occurrence.  Ongoing Emerg

ency Response training provides the personnel and resources familiarity with procedures and available resources.  

Compliance Audit:

A compliance audit was conducted in accordance with RMP/PSM requirements by an outside consultant in 1998, 2001 and 2004. The audits were to evaluate the 
adequacy of the PSM and RMP programs and provide recommendations of improvements.  The major recommendation to improve the overall safety of the facility was 
to review the site security issue.  The Safety Committee is reviewing the situation and a plan of action is pending.

Risk Reduction Initiatives:

Consistent with the City historical pro-active track record, several risk reduction programs are in progress. First, authorization has been granted by the City of Oxnard 
Council to change from gaseous chlorine/sulfur dioxide to liquid bleach/sodium bisulfite as the primary treatment chemicals.  Switching to liquid, the potential risk 
of a gaseous release will be eliminated.  A reduced amount of stand-by chlorine and sulfur dioxide will be maintained in the event of liquid chemical shipment
